abstracts.cdata!:
This document presents an analysis of
            potential social and environmental impacts linked to the
            reforms supported by the Fourth Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit Project, resulting from its sectoral adjustment,
            mostly those measures linked to rural development, but also
            due to the privatization of ONATEL (telecommunications
            utility) and the energy sector reforms, including as well,
            those investments in education and health. Rural development
            entails actions focused on agricultural diversification, and
            the liberalization of the cotton sub-sector. Although
            diversification efforts will likely improve agricultural
            extension and production, due to improved soil fertility
            through the adoption of nutritional substances, the use of
            pesticides may threaten the environment. Thus, it is
            recommended that appropriate use of pesticides be
            implemented, in accordance with standard international best
            practices, following training and capacity building as
            necessary. Soil and water conservation is being pursued at a
            national level, through community participation and village
            groups, who contribute their resources and efforts.
            Concerning the cotton sub-sector, the parastatal enterprise
            SOFITEX, conducted an environmental audit of its
            establishment and cotton gins, to determine cost estimates
            for an environmental management, and identify best
            practices. Similarly, Onatel conducted an environmental
            audit prior to privatization, whose recommendations are
            being incorporated in procurement and contract documents, to
            be enforced during implementation. Construction for, and
            installation of power lines and interconnections, as well as
            new central power stations, should comply with standard
            international regulations. As for improvements in the
            education and health sectors, specific environmental
            management measures will apply for schools construction,
            with adequate infrastructure (water supply and sanitation
            measures), while particular attention will be given to
            medical wastes disposal.
